coredata.dc:title: A particle-hole model for light scattering by simple fluids
coredata.dc:creator: Keyes, T.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The intensity, I, of depolarized light scattered by simple fluids is calculated by modeling the fluid as a dilute gas of dielectric spheres at low density and as a dilute gas of spherical holes in a dielectric continuum at high density. It is shown that a pair of spheres has more inherent scattering power than a pair of holes. Thus, at liquid density, I is smaller than would be predicted by using gas-phase scattering theory plus liquid-state statistics, as has generally been done in the past; the implications of our result for existing theories are discussed.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 70, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 February 1980 A PARTICLE-HOLE MODEL FOR LIGHT SCATTERING BY SIMPLE FLUIDS + T KEYES^ Sterling Chemistry Laboratory Yale University, New Haven Connecticut 06520, USA Received 24 October 1979, in final form 4 December 1979 The intensity,/, of depolarized light scattered by simple fluids is calculated by modeling the fluid as a dilute gas of dielec- tric spheres at low density and as a dilute gas of spherical holes in a dielectric continuum at high density It is shown that a pair of spheres has more inherent scattering power than a pair of holes Thus, at liquid density, / is smaller than would be predicted by using gas-phase scattering theory plus liquid-state statistics, as has generally been done in the past; the impli- cations of our result for existing theories are discussed 1. Introduction One oftlie more interesting current cliallenges to theorists in the area of light scattering is to explain the sub- stantial reduction in depolarized intensity,/, which occurs for fluids composed of spherical [1] and nonspherical [2] molecules upon passage from dense gas to liquid- In this paper, we discuss scattering from isotropic particles. The phenomenon is qualitatively understood, density fluctuations are suppressed in a liquid, the system appears more uniform to the light beam, and less scattering occurs. However, existing calculations [3] of/ for argon (a good "test case"), while showing some decrease in the liquid, still predict == 10 times too much intensity. A light scattering intensity calculation proceeds in two steps- (a) an approximation must be made to the mul- tiple-scattering series for a given configuration of tlie fluid, (b) an average must be performed over configurations The suppression of density fluctuations in the liquid is, of course, contained in (b) Most existing theories [3,4] have tned to carry out a satisfactory, liquid-like treatment of(b), while basically, in various guises, using a low density, gas-like treatment of (a) The work ofThibeau et al. [4] is intuitively very appealing in this regard. The fluid is modeled as a lattice whose sites may be occupied by (e g , argon) atoms At low density, few sites are oc- cupied, and little scattering occurs. At high density, the lattice is nearly a perfect one, which, like a vacuum, does not scatter, in this case, "holes", which are few, may be considered as doing the scattering The intensity is then calculated at low density and at high density, and an expression is chosen which reproduces both limits A simple such expression is [4] I=c(p*)2(l-p'')^(pf), (i) where C is a constant, p* is the density, p, in units of the perfect-lattice density; 1 p* is the hole density, P),, and S11 is an average over the density-dependent particle pair distribution function ofr~6. Eq (1) predicts that / vanishes at high as well as low densities in a way that is physically transparent It is important, for our purposes, to note that the coefficients which multiply the p* -> 0 (p*)2 behavior of/and the ?*-> ! (p]S)2 behavior differ only as511 varies with p*;S11 will surely vary, but, presumably, not by an immense amount. Thus, even though a liquid is not really a lattice, and such parameters as the perfect-lattice density and the lattice spacing must re- * Supported by the NSF * Dreyfus Teacher Scholar 194 Volume 70, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS IS February 1980 main slightly adjustable, we find the particle hole approach attractive. At the least, it may be regarded as a model which demonstrates the physical phenomena of interest. In all their work, Thibeau et al. [4] have used an approximation to scattering theory (step (a) in the last para- graph) which is valid for low densities That is, they have worked out the consequences of the statistics of the lattice model [step (b)] at low and high density, for those scattering events which are dominant at low density. In the language which we have used in two recent papers [5], Thibeau et al. calculate IQQ, the "double double" scattering intensity ("double" refers to light scattered twice by two particles). We have argued that, at liquid den- sities, one cannot assume that / == IJ)D'> an<^ tnat herein ^les tne discrepancy between theory and experiment men- tioned earlier The particle hole model provides a natural vehicle to check our conjectures. At low density, / sa IQQ, and no more need be done. At high density, however, it is true that / s= I^Q, the intensity of light scattered by two holes- /^p ls not tne same as /pp evaluated at high density, but is a resummation of the multiple-particle scattering se- ries. Thus, rather than calculate/ ., at high and low density, it is logical to calculate IQQ a1 low density and/"} at high density, with, possibly, a consequent combination of the two limits in a closed-form expression. If that closed form predicts an intensity which is significantly less than /DD [e g., eq. (1)] at liquid densities, then, within the model, our earlier criticisms of assuming / s /pp are sustained. In the rest of the paper, we cany out the indicated program, with some modifications. Since a liquid is not an imperfect crystal, the lattice formulation is not essential to a particle hole theory. Thus, we shall model the low- density gas as dielectric spheres in a vacuum, and the high-density liquid as spherical holes in a dielectric con- tinuum The continuum particle hole theory is more tractable than the lattice version, and, arguably, more real- istic as well. 2. General scattering theory Fixman [6] lias shown how to construct a localized source for light scattering from a system which consists of a subsystem of interest surrounded by a continuum of dielectric constant e^; the source is S(r) = P(r) - [(e^ - l)/47r] -(r) , (2) P is the polarization, and E is the Maxwell electric field. The Fixman source has the essential property of vanishing everywhere but in the subsystem of interest In our case, the subsystem is also a dielectric, so we have P(r) = [(egg - 1 )/47r] E(r), r subsystem , = [(ec - l)/47r] '(r), r continuum, (3) and S(r) = [(ess e(;)/4ir] E(r), r e subsystem , =0, r continuum (4) If we let the electric field far from the subsystem, EQ, lie along the z axis, then, in arbitrary units 1= fdrdr'^SX(r)SX(r')), (5) where < > denotes an equilibrium ensemble average. The integral is over the scattering volume, and the space out- side the scattering volume is assumed [6] to be filled with continuum. According to eqs. (4) and (5), we require the electric field within the subsystem A straightforward exercise in classical electrostatics yields E(r) = -0 + (l/6c) JdrT(r-r). (6) should be compared with a more familiar result, in which "Q is the field be- fore the introduction of the sample, e;; is absent, and P appears in place of 5'. That result naturally yields an expan- sion about a vacuum, while the zero order solution ofeq (6) is the field in a uniform continuum with dielectric constant e;;. In theories of the latter type, as Fixman has shown, S replaces P, the source for scattering from near vacuum. Either expansion may be used in principle, but eq. (6) is indicated in practice, since P is nonzero in the continuum and does not provide a source localized to the scattering volume. Eq. (6) may be rewritten with the use ofeq. Low density. Scattering from two spheres Since a single dielectric sphere gives no depolarized scattering, we have at low density, I=N(N-\) f drdr'<S^(r)S^(r')). High density. Scattering from two holes The calculation of scattering from two holes proceeds in perfect correspondence with the calculation in sec- tion 3 In eq. (8), N^ replaces JV. We now have 655 = I (subsystem is vacuum) and e,; = e, where e is the dielectric constant of the liquid Our two approximations then give (I now denotes hole number 1, ..) (19) and (15) from unity is known to be small, so, to good accuracy, //| o|2^= Cp2a4 f drg<2)(r)r-4, p ^0 , 0 oa = Cp^e2 / d/-^t2^1)(/ )^-4, Ph ^ 0 - (20) u 197 Volume 70, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 February 1980 To proceed further, it is necessary to deal with^211), a complicated problem in general. Suppose the atoms are hard spheres; then, hm g^(.r)=0, r<2a, p->0 =1, r>2a. (21) It seems reasonable to assume, for simplicity, thatg^2^ is also given by eq (21). Holes clearly cannot overlap, as this would correspond to removing two overlapping atoms from the "perfect" system, so the first line ofeq. (21) holds for^t21^. It is surely likely that pairs of holes are not randomly distributed for r> la (second line) but that problem is beyond the scope of this article. Note that we are not assuming g^(p - 0) = g^(p^ - -0). Our as- sumptions are in accord with those made in the lattice model, and the point of this article is to solve a new scat- tering problem, not to introduce improved statistics Thus, laa4?2, p-^0, "e2^4?2, Ph^O. We finally obtain / <x a4?2, low density; :ot4{el/2(l^/6)[(e+2)/(2e+l)]p<'}4p2, high density. (24) Due to the quantity in braces (denoted A) in eq (24), the coefficient multiplying p2 at low density differs from the coefficient multiplying p2 at high density. This is a direct consequence of our solving different scattering prob- lems at low and high density. Taking e = 1.5 and p* = 0.8 as typical of an inert gas liquid, we find A= 0 45, A4 = 0.04 Thus, within our model, the coefficient multiplying p2 at high densities is very much smaller than the p2 coefficient at low densities However, the lattice work [4] shows that the high and low density coefficients for double-double scattering will mainly differ as S11 differs between low and high densities, a factor of 0.04 is in- conceivable in this regard, and, in any event, would be related to statistics and not to scattering theory. Thus we have /pi) > /(liquids), even though /pp -> 0 as ? -> 0, / vanishes faster, in agreement with our earlier work [5]. We have basically shown that two holes have less scattering power than two particles. An interpolation with the form ofeq (1) is unsatisfactory, one simple possibility is/" A^4?2?2/^ + p2^4 1)]. head.ce:title: A particle-hole model for light scattering by simple fluids

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Sterling Chemistry Laboratory Yale University, New Haven Connecticut 06520, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The intensity, I, of depolarized light scattered by simple fluids is calculated by modeling the fluid as a dilute gas of dielectric spheres at low density and as a dilute gas of spherical holes in a dielectric continuum at high density. It is shown that a pair of spheres has more inherent scattering power than a pair of holes. Thus, at liquid density, I is smaller than would be predicted by using gas-phase scattering theory plus liquid-state statistics, as has generally been done in the past; the implications of our result for existing theories are discussed.
